Want me to do somethin' about this?
Mr. Haller?
Got you the good stuff, Hayley...
Man's got your ride ready...
.when Not Guilty Two gets to four thousand miles, that's two cars ready, that's enough to start the airport runs...
You gettin' any of this, Mr.
Mr. Haller? Got that thing you asked for.
It's called, lookin' out for your blood.
Just keep your speed up, Earl.
Earl-- buds.
This is Haller.
On my way to Lancaster for a calendar call. Why, have you got something?
Van Nuys by eleven could be hard--
He's already got a lawyer?--
A million? What'd they book him on?
Has the D.A. filed yet?
Bring me around to the employee's gate, I'll talk my way in.
I'm at the courthouse. Give me the name.
That's not how you spell the wheel but I got it, thanks.
You're on my Christmas list, Val.
Harold. Hard Case.
Don't hide from your lawyer, Harold, you know what I want to talk about.
Listen. when the judge comes in he's going to want to know if we're ready for trial...
We're not and you know why not. You haven't paid me. Rule one, remember Rule one, Harold? I get paid or I don't work.
Right, you have my money, I don't.
Harold-- I looked at the list of people I trust, and you know what?
Pay close attention, Harold.
Mickey Haller for the defense, your honor. If I may, I'd like to carry this over.
I'm having trouble locating a witness, your honor. An indispensable witness. A Mr. Green.
I hope so, your honor. As your honor knows, Mr. Green can be hard to track down.

And so does Judge Powell. He spent a lot of years as a defense lawyer, so he knows all about having to chase "Mr. Green," and he doesn't look kindly on defendants who don't pay their attorneys. Now do you get it, Harold?
This is Haller.
Actually I'm in my office. On my way to court in Van Nuys.
Oh yeah: "This is the franchise, Mick." According to Valenzuela every case is "the franchise." I'd have paid my mortgage ten times over by now--
Sounds like the media might be interested. Call Sticks, tell him to show up. Any other calls?
Good. Then I can go to County lock-
Ignore them, you're doing fine.
What can I say, Lorn, I've got a soft spot for redheads. Why do you think I married you?
Lucky for you there was a cure.
Fine, Eddie, how's it with you?
If you want me to work you've gat to pay me.
That's long gone. I could tell you half went to the aerial-photo expert. He's going to blow the state's case by showing that the DEA violated the air space over Harold's farm by flying too low...
Ten. I'm flying the guy in from Kodak in New York, he wants business class...
I don't. And I don't want to.
You had the whole ten ready. What if you'd backed me down to five?
Louis Roulet?
My name is Michael Haller. I had a call.
You want me to represent you for your first appearance. I get twenty-
Keep your voice down. And don't say anything about the case, not til I've got you out on bail. Okay?
I understand your family lawyer's in court?
Is he ready to post bail?
Okay, tell me about yourself. How old are you?
Ties to the community? You grow up here, go to school?
"Windsor Estates?"
How much did you make last year?
If I'm going to get you out I need to know everything.
They'll have one for you out there.
Listen. They've put some heavy charges on you. The DA will probably ask for No-Bail...
I said they're going to ask it.
So if I checked your record--
We're not talking about the case, remember? Not even to the judge.
Today's about setting arraignment, period. You say nothing.
I'm gonna try, Louis.
One more thing: There are lots of lawyers. Why pick me?
What case?
You remember the name or anything?
Are you the prosecutor who used to have the Roulet case?
Rules are rules.
Depends. You going for no-bail?
If he did it.
I love it when you're sarcastic.
How's Hayley?
How about this weekend?
We'll see, Val...
Cecil Dobbs?
Boy?
He did look a little frail. My advice is, let Mr. Valenzuela fix you up with a bond and take "the boy" home.
No good. Assessing it will take days. By then Louis might be carrying somebody's child.
So just tap Val for the bond, spring Louis, and take him to your office. We'll meet there at Four.
Yep. Media's already picked us up.
I saw you in there filming. What's your name?
You freelancing on this, Sticks?
How much?
How much will they pay you for what you shot today?
Suppose we take it off your hands for eight.
Or do we make it a thousand.
I can expense this, right?
Then let's talk about my fees.
I'll need a hundred thousand up front. Working off five-fifty an hour, it'll come to another hundred thousand if we go to trial. That's estimating the trial at a week.
I take it that's not a problem.
We've got it if we want it. I'd still like to know the state's case, what they've got on him...
I've got an hour til he's released.
Yeah he does.
You don't even know who the Mick was. You don't look good, Gloria.
Something new for you, getting booked on possession of coke, along with the usual.
And your next was a cop.
We did a pre-trial rehab, last time. The D.A. won't go for it again. You may have to do some jail here.
Yeah you can. They've got programs in jail, too. Look, you've had a long run. Maybe after this you can finally get out of the life.
Okay, tell me what happened.
The one who paid you coke instead of money?
Do you know who he was?
Did you screen him?
off what, his driver's license?
Hector what? Last name. Think.
Moya. Hector "Arrande" Moya is what you get if you run a trace. He's Colombian, a fugitive from a Grand Jury indictment down in Florida.
Leslie? They want him a lot.
She'll give you his motel and room number.
That's a No. Location only. Your guys take it from there. My investigator says Hector hasn't checked out yet.
You drop charges, and all she does is a Pre-trial Rehabilitation. The facility at USC-Med would be nice.
Or do I take this straight to the Feds?
Mrs. Windsor, this is Raul Levin.
I'm going to need that to come from your son, Mrs. Windsor.
You can give him the money so he can write the check. But I want the check to come from Louis. He's my client and that's got to be clear from the start. No offense.
Thank you. I'll expect you to support your son through this in other ways. If you're willing.
It's good to know you'll be there when we need you.
We'll be going over the case. The D.A. could make you testify about what you hear. Attorney privilege doesn't cover you.
I've got no trouble believing that.
I say we get started.
Our first choice is whether we waive our right to a speedy trial.
You sure? You can stretch things out, enjoy your freedom. Most clients...
Fine. We go to trial right away.
It might not be jail.
Time to tell me what happened.
Morgan's, that's a singles bar, right?
Raul, what's the file say about the girl?
Did you know her before last night?
But she was still with a guy?
Raul. Check that file you've got and see if the Police report has any of this.
Raul's already worked us a little miracle. He's managed to score a copy of the discovery file, everything the D.A.'s got. They'd have to turn it over eventually but it could have been weeks.
All they've got is, Louis shows up and beats the crap out of her?
Just keep telling me.
You see what he was driving?
So he leaves, and you go in...
What was what?
Okay then. What do you remember next?
Go on, Louis.
Set it up how?
Louis: You said she opened the door a crack. Did you see her face?
And then she clocks him?
So our case is, she beat herself up?
We're saying, she pounded her face into hamburger meat, or had her boyfriend do it, hoping some far-
Okay, the police report. Let's hear how Reggie tells it.
Does it say he knocked her down?
Raul, are his prints on there?
Okay, how's she say he went down?
If everything she said is a lie, this will be the easiest case ever.
The way Louis tells it...
.it's just quirky enough.
To be true. Maybe it went down just like he says.
Anyway there's a. chance.
Yeah. But you know what my father said about innocent clients...
That's right. Because if you screw up and he goes to prison, it scars you for life. There's only one verdict. You've got to put an N.G.
Okay, you know the moves. Make the rounds, check out Morgan's Bar...
And Regina Campo. The way Louis says she came on's got me wondering.
Earl lays this stuff on me.
I never keep him this late.
A while ago. But he likes driving, keeps him out of trouble... He's taking courses, too, in music.
You get used to it. Besides, Tupac, he helps me understand my clients.
Not Louis, no. Louis is my franchise player, he pays for all the rest...
Never heard of him.
Lorna made me my schedule.
I'm all over it. How's she doing?
Moonlight becomes you.
Thanks.
Me too, baby.
Darius I told you--
What couldn't wait, Raul?
Do the cops have this?
You're exceedingly beautiful.
It means he's right-handed. But the facial blows were from the left...
So everything's backwards...
I told you you were beautiful.
Yeah?
Mickey Haller. Here to see Louis.
There won't be any showings in Pelican Bay.
It's a supermax prison where they send violent sex offenders. You'll fit in real good in your loafers.
You lied to me, Louis. I'm about to go and see the new prosecutor, who's doing everything he can to put you away, and now I find out you've been lying.
Tell me about Reggie Campo.
You didn't tell me. That you were going to pay her for sex.
You think it's hard to find out somebody's not Snow White?
Why didn't you tell me this in Cecil's office?
This changes things. You see that, don't you?
Alright I will. You know that guy on the Venice boardwalk? The one who has all those plates spinning on sticks?
Just listen. A bunch of spinning plates: that's the state's case. In the middle is a big one. It's a fucking platter. And if that falls it takes the others down with it.
The big plate is the victim. The only witness against you. I knock her down, the act is over and the crowd goes home. No trial.
We've lost time. You concealed from me the fact that could do it. It comes down to why.
Why would a guy with a Porsche and a Rolex need a knife to get sex from a woman who sells it anyway?
Yes. Young hot-shot named Ted Minton. He wants to give me the discovery file. Poor guy doesn't know that Raul already got it. He's new to felonies but he's no dope.
No promises, Louis.
Detective Kurlen.
Thanks for clearing that up.
Is Minton back yet?--
I haven't talked to him.
He got life, but he'll be out. I don't know when.
You don't have to remind me you were lead dick on that.
I had a client once, he decapitated his ex-wife, then kept her head in the refrigerator.
The D.A. got greedy. Tried to pile on two unsolved murders, trick up evidence to stick my guy with them.
I don't know. I never heard of him after that.
No. Fuck the D.A.
I've got a question first.
You have something to play this on?
Look Ted, let's cut the bullshit.
Offer? You're making an offer?
.What am I missing here?...
Go on, I'll hold your ice cream.
There's something right in front of me and I'm not seeing it.
Daddy's got to talk to somebody.
That was before I found out you were still lying to me.
You know what that is? It's a picture of your knife. The one you had on you when you went to Reggie Campos. The one the cops have.
That's why Ted Minton didn't care when I told him Reggie's a prostitute. What's it matter, when he's got a knife with her blood and your initials on it?

That's right. The file Raul got us was a loaded deck. The cops must have been on to him, because they used it to set us up. So we'd think they had nothing, when in fact they had enough to put your Hugo Boss, golf-playing ass away for twenty years!
Explain to me why you lied about the knife.

What are you now, a lawyer? A clever, third-rate fucking lawyer with smart-ass technicalities? "You said it wasn't yours"-- What you should have said was, "I had a knife but this isn't it!" What did you think, it would just go away?
You brought a murder weapon to a meeting with a prostitute, Louis!
Then kindly tell me why you went to her apartment with a custom-made knife, serrated tip, with "LR"
You always carry it.
Who was there?
That's quite a story, Louis.
Your mother will have to testify.
I don't give a damn what you think we want. From now on you do what I tell you while I try this case. Do I make myself clear?
If she wasn't so darn heavy I'd carry her all night, I swear.
It turned into a rough week. Being with Hayley was the only high.
I stopped going. Too much of a scene.
If I start again, what?
I'll keep it in mind.
Okay.
You won't make it to the bar...
Yeah, that's exactly what--
So Ted talked to you about Corliss?
Nah, nothing I don't know, they always use a professional snitch...
I mean Corliss has done this before, right?
How about we go somewhere to eat?
So we can talk about our daughter.
The fun's watching her.
He was hiding something, I thought it might be a jailhouse snitch...
one good turn. I'll drive you.
How'd she get in here?
So she sleeps in here a lot?
Don't you remember what we talked about last night?
I can't win with you--
Sorry. It's work.
Martha Renteria.
But you told Kurlen you were in her apartment. He didn't have that, he doesn't even have any prints...
Nobody saw any "other guy"...
Plus the coroner says her vagina was brutalized...
Three people saw you throwing a knife into the L.A. River...
If all you did was fuck her then why didn't you leave any prints?
But your semen was on the towel, you forgot you wiped your penis on that towel...
It's not gonna make.
Jesus they want the death penalty!
I'm not going to ask you how you are because I know.
Look. I need to ask some questions.
I am trying to make it right.
Tell me again about the Cobra Room.
You said there was another guy...
Guard!
I need him to look at these.
But if you won't let him close to the glass, how can he see them?
All right, but can you stay a minute? If he IDs one of these mug-
Godammit.
Try. See if one is the guy.
I helped myself.
It wasn't you. The cops set you up.
You're right, I don't. But I know who his partner was, when he was in homicide. Kurlen.
Don't bother. We've got bigger problems.
Cell phones don't work too well where I was.
I came to tell you a story. About Jesus Martinez.
It's about what happened after he left Martha Renteria's apartment.
He never killed her. He went there, had sex, flushed the condom--
And then went home. The story starts after he left.
The real killer. She lets him in.
Maybe he fakes like it's still Martinez and he forgot something.
Do you need to ask what kind of knife it was, based on the wounds?
Or whose face Martinez picked out of the mug-shots I brought him?
Of course the story goes on from there. From there it's about the lawyer Martinez gets himself...

The lawyer who just assumes he did it because of the DNA. The lawyer who gets him the best deal he can, and feels pretty good, because the deal keeps his client off Death Row... and this guy, this lawyer, he's all about the deal, see?
I just saw him and he's twenty-six going on forty. He's a little guy.
He has a type. Roulet. It's more than a type, Renteria and Campo, you put their faces together you get the same face...
Listen, I was thinking about this the whole way down on the plane--
Yeah but tonight he sees who she looks like.
Right. And he's right back there.
We're talking about a killer at work. You know that video from the bar? Just like you, he saw that Mr.
He knows what he's doing. Reggie's the luckiest woman alive.
You find out. Dig into Roulet.
"All you'll find is parking tickets," I don't buy that anymore.
I can't. He's my client.
I was thinking about that on the plane too: He was worried I might hear about the case and put it together. But if he was my client, I'd be bound to keep my mouth shut and protect him.
I told you: He knows what he's doing.
I'm working on it.
This is Haller...
Maggie, no, I was up in San Francisco for the day...
You always were too smart for me.
Fine, I look forward to it.
Noon, I'll do that. See you then.
What the hell are you doing here?
Get out of my house! Now!
I said Get up! Get up and get out of this house!
You don't come near this house again, do you understand me? We aren't friends, we aren't partners, you're my client, eriod--
Fucken don't.
That's it, Hayley, get in her way!
It's okay, honey!
This is Haller...
No, but I've got a big trial next month, attempted rape and murder.
How did you know?
I'm a suspect?
I was watching my daughter play soccer. A couple of dozen people can confirm I was there.

He was a hell of an ex-cop, is what he was. Crimes Against Persons, back in Chicago. And yeah he was gay, and what the hell's that got to do with it? If the murder was some kind of gay thing, why'd they ransack the office? Isn't it obvious they were looking for something to do with his work?
You know your garage door's open?
Raul's murder.
I've been with the cops. They can't tie Roulet to it, because your ankle bracelet doesn't put him near the house.
Did the cops ask you where you were this morning, Val?
Somehow, some way, Louis killed Raul Levin. And it didn't show up on the trace.
Maybe you didn't know what he was going to do--
Where'd you get the money for an eight thousand dollar TV, Val?
That's the idea, y'know. Car service, with the Lincolns-- Drive the illustrious turds of our city back and forth to LAX--
Lemme ask you something. Corliss.
Maggie-- Raul. Did I get him killed?
I can't do this anymore.
It's me. Haller.
Look, I-- just checked my phone messages. It turns out Raul called me. Just before he was killed. I didn't know.

In San Quentin. Right.
No-- No, that's it. Then the dog barked, somebody was at the door.
Yeah... just, I'll let you know if I think of anything. About his cell-
Gloria I'm not here about you. I'm here about me. I need your help.
Better make it fast.
That's right. Unless it's one you're going to commit.
Now? Now? Why now, are you telling me this...
Come with me.
You son of a bitch. You killed Raul.
How did you do it? The trace said you weren't even in Glendale...
You piece of shit, do you think you have this wired? You don't!
I want my gun, Louis--
I'm sorry, your honor.
Ladies and gentlemen of the jury...
My name's Michael Haller, and I'm representing Louis Roulet.
Mr. Minton doesn't want to use the word prostitute for the woman who's supposed to be Louis's victim. He needn't worry, this case isn't about how she makes her money...
Thinks?
Let her try. But it may not matter.
I mean, Corliss isn't on the witness list. It could be Ted Minton is holding him back. He won't use him until he has to.

Why did you write that she didn't know him?
So, she just opened the door at ten o'clock to a stranger?
Was there blood on his right hand?
Objection, I don't think Mr.
Mr. Talbot, are you right or left-
Left. And isn't it true that before you left Regina Campo asked you to strike her repeatedly in the face?
Part of the defense theory, Judge.
Do you know a prostitute named...
Shaquille Barton? "Shaquilla Shakels" is her work name.
And if I brought her here and she said you had struck her with your left hand...
With a strong left. Thank you.
This warrant is bullshit--
I don't anymore. It was stolen.
I know. My father represented him.
Because I knew who took it.
A client. He told me, so I couldn't turn him in without breaking a trust. They do that.
Go crazy. You've got the warrant.
You can't do ballistics on a box.
You can match casings to a slug that's fifty years old?
Detective? How long will ballistics take?
I'm in the middle of a trial.
Worry about yourself, Ted. You're dying the death of a thousand razors up there and you don't even know it.
Listen, you little shit: This gun-
Your honor, prejudicial--
That's it, keep acting like you pull the strings.
Ms. Campo have you engaged an attorney to sue Mr. Roulet for the events of March Sixth?
But have you talked to an attorney?
I asked if you talked to one. About a possible lawsuit.
Did you ask if you could sue Mr.
If you wish, you can tell the jurors.
Okay, let's go back to the night at Morgan's. Had you ever seen Louis Roulet before that night?
Ever noticed he wore a Rolex watch?
Or that he drove one of two cars, a Porsche or a Range Rover?
And what made you approach him?
With prostitutes. To go to a hotel, or their apartments...?
So how do you know they left? Maybe they just went out for a smoke...
But you just testified that you never saw Mr. Roulet drive! Now you saw him leave with a prostitute like yourself. Which is it?
Do you know the difference between a Porsche and a Range Rover?
The women he left with, when you saw them again, had they been beaten or injured?
But girls in your profession talk about customers, don't you? Warn each other if someone's a freak...
And how many had warned you about Louis Roulet?
So you believed you'd be safe?
So you thought he could solve your need for money?
No? Isn't that why we're sitting here? Because you zeroed in on him?
What did the napkin say, Ms. Campo?
And your price?
It's a hard line of work...
In fact, haven't you told friends you were looking for a way out?
And so, isn't it true-- nothing would be easier to understand--
Yes, we've heard you say that--
Judge may I ask the witness to stand up?
Now if you please, walk over to my client.
This is the man you broke free from, overpowered, knocked out?
How much do you weigh, Ms. Campo?
I've got no further questions for the witness, your honor.
Not worried enough.
Why would he need protection?
But has Louis ever been the subject of such a crime?
Go on, please.
We've had an offer. Want to spend six months in county jail?
I know: The only verdict's Not Guilty. Okay. We'll get there.
Don't touch me, Louis. You want to show your gratitude give me my gun back.
I thought so.
You still sure you want me to put you on the stand?
Then get some rest tonight, you're up next.
There's something I need you to get me, Earl.
Yes. No deal.
The defense calls Louis Ross Roulet, your honor.
And what happened when you turned?
That was all?
But, there was blood on your jacket and your left hand...
Are you left-handed?
You didn't strike Ms. Campo with your left fist?
Threaten to rape her, or kill her?--
You're angry. Why?
Nothing further, Judge.
Your honor, the defense rests.
The state still has an obligation to disclose the identity--
How I'm the one who shot Raul?
I'd say so. I'm being set up for his murder. Couple of detectives from Glendale are following me around, just waiting for the go-
Bad timing, bad client, me being dumb...
I can't talk to you about my clients. How is Hayley?
She won't. Not if I play it right.
I'm working on it. I have a plan.
Bill, I'm getting coffee. Any for you?
Hey, is that the custody list? Can I see if any of my no-good clients are on it?
Minton's putting on Corliss. He's got him in lock-up already...
You said she had mealtimes to work it...
I'll take my chances. Meantime did you serve Kurlen?
Yes you did.
Now go, and be ready for my call.
Subpoena to appear as a witness?
Judge? Who is this witness? Why wasn't I told before now?
That was good. Now leave it to me.
I do share my client's outrage, your honor. I'd at least like to know how long the state has been sitting on this testimony...
This is incredible...
No, Judge, we all know what this is, this is a jailhouse snitch, and anything he'd say would be a lie--
--I just want my objection noted.
Can I ask one indulgence? Can I step into the hallway and make a call to an investigator? For whatever good it will do at this late date.
Put your watch at quarter of. At ten fifteen you enter the room.
With the printouts.
How many times have you been arrested, Mr. Corliss?
So you know how the system works?
And sometimes that means ratting out fellow inmates, is that it?
Thank you, your honor. But I'll rephrase: How many times have you snitched on an inmate? Testified against a fellow inmate for the prosecution?
Four times? People just come up and tell you they committed crimes so you can testify against them--
So you and my client were friends--
And he just said what you said he said, about what the woman "deserved," and then you went back to talking about cigarettes?
You... Wait...
No more questions, your honor.
You tell me! What did you say to this guy?
How? How am I doing this?
How does he know this?
If you didn't tell him this shit somebody did. Who? Start thinking!
A moment with my staff, Judge?
It's all here, right? You go now, I don't want anyone talking to you.
I don't know what's going on here, but it won't matter if it's two murders or a hundred if I can show he's a liar--
Just tell me if there's anything else he knows. Anything else I have to stay away from.
It doesn't matter. If I destroy him none of it counts...
Dwayne, if I can call you that--
Don't they also call you D.J.? For example, down in Phoenix, right?
Because you know, my assistant, she was just reading on the internet about D.J. Corliss-- arrested in Phoenix, 1989 on drug charges--
You remember Fred Bentley, right?
Sure you do. You testified that he confessed to you the crime he was charged with-- rape of a ten-year-
Then I'd like you to read this to us, D.J. It's a printout of a news story from the Arizona Star, 1997, that's eight years after he was convicted. I ask that it be admitted into evidence--
I've marked the paragraph.
That's enough.

Was that because the police were complicit in your confession?

Sorry. I have no more questions.
He's going to see his boss. To decide what to do before the judge comes down with a directed verdict.

Let it go. You're getting what you want, I'm getting you off...
I want the gun.

Yeah, and you'll have to explain how you got it. But you know what?
When they stick that needle in your arm, that will be me.
Please tell me you've got enough on Louis for the murder of Renteria.
What ticket?

I said I'd never do this. Ask you to violate your parole.
Yeah?

--it's my family, Val. Maggie, Hayley-- they're in danger.
